awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Statistical Tools for Tracking Synaptic Plasticity in Neural Spiking Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop new statistical tools for understanding how synapses between neurons change over time. Synaptic changes are the basis for flexible information processing, learning, memory, and recovery from injury in the brain, but, since neural activity is highly variable, studying synaptic changes in behaving animals is a major challenge. The research described in this proposal will address this challenge by developing novel statistical methods that infer changes in synaptic strength based on neural spiking activity. In parallel with the research plan, this project will also implement a set of tutorials and workshops to improve the training of undergraduate and graduate students in neural data analysis. These resources aim to improve the reliability and reproducibility of neuroscience research and better prepare experimental neuroscientists to contribute to and benefit from large-scale data and code sharing.

The proposed research will develop a statistical model-based framework that allows time-varying synaptic weights to be inferred from spiking data alone and apply these methods to characterize plasticity on multiple timescales in vivo. Through close collaboration with experimentalists, the models will first be validated and refined on isolated, well studied neural systems with known connectivity. The models will then be extended to address the additional sources of variability in larger populations of neurons with unknown connectivity. This framework will be applied to determine 1) how synaptic plasticity interacts with brain state and 2) how short- and long-term plasticity interact in vivo. By using multi-electrode spike recordings, the statistical tools developed here will allow synaptic plasticity to be quantified on a larger scale than previously possible and will allow new comparisons of plasticity across cell types, brain areas, and behaviors. By shedding light on how synapses change over time, this work may ultimately lead to a better understanding of disease and injury and advance the development of neurally-inspired technologies.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the development of new data analysis methods for analyzing neural signals and, specifically, to track how synapses between neurons change over time. The grant supported three primary research aims as well as education in neural data analysis.

Aim 1: Develop and validate statistical tools for estimating synaptic weight changes from spikes. Although many studies investigate synaptic connections using intracellular signals, the overarching goal of this project was to create new statistical tools to study synapses using extracellular recordings or spikes. Using simulations and data from controlled settings we first developed and tested methods for tracking short-term plasticity (Ghanbari et al., PLoS Computational Biology, 2017). We developed two approaches: one based on estimating biophysical parameters and another based on fitting a phenomenological regression model. This work showed that short-term synaptic plasticity can be accurately estimated from spikes using both methods for realistic experimental recording lengths and firing rates.

Aim 2: Develop tools to remove confounds and characterize relationships between brain state and synaptic plasticity in vivo. We next applied these statistical tools to describe short-term synaptic plasticity in a wide range of synaptic connections in vivo (Ghanbari et al., Journal of Neuroscience, 2020). This work showed that short-term plasticity is highly diverse in vivo and that typical synaptic connections are not well described by models that treat synapses as static. We also found that short-term synaptic plasticity in the sensory periphery appears to differ depending on the stimulus that is presented. Statistical models that account for plasticity can predict these changes.

We also developed a novel method for detecting putative synapses in large-scale spike recordings (Ren et al., Journal of Neurophysiology, 2020). This approach is robust to slow, potentially confounding, correlations and uses information about cell type (excitatory vs inhibitory) and synaptic transmission to better detect which pairs of neurons have synaptic connections.

Aim 3: Develop tools to model multiple plasticity mechanisms simultaneously. Short-term plasticity affects information transmission and may act to filter neural signals. However, long-term changes in synaptic strength can also occur, and these changes that are thought to underlie learning, memory, and recovery from injury. We, thus developed an additional model that is able to simultaneously track both short-term and long-term plasticity (Wei and Stevenson, Neural Computation, 2021). Using large-scale data from many brain regions, we then demonstrated how short-term plasticity can lead to predictable changes in apparent synaptic strength on long timescales (Ren et al., Journal of Neuroscience, 2022).

Statistical tools for detecting and characterizing synapses from spikes have many potential future applications in systems neuroscience studying learning and memory as they occur. In this project, we developed new methods for detecting putative synaptic connections from spikes, as well as models for tracking short- and long-term plasticity. We validated these models on simulations and in simple, controlled experimental settings, and also applied these methods to in vivo experimental recordings. Our results suggest that synaptic strengths during natural, ongoing brain activity are highly malleable, but, in many cases, can be explained by known mechanisms of short-term synaptic plasticity. This work also demonstrated how widely-used models of functional connectivity with static connections fail to describe substantial variation in synaptic strengths over time and provides tools for characterizing this variation. Code for all methods is publicly available online, and a preprint reviewing this work is available (Stevenson, arXiv, 2023).

Education: The grant also supported the work of graduate and undergraduate students who received interdisciplinary training in neural data analysis. We developed 1) a library of tutorials that allows students to learn and practice common analyses on publicly available neural data, 2) course material and training resources that better prepare neurophysiology students for data analysis, and 3) a graduate-level, project-based course where students investigated new data analysis methods relevant to their research. Resources for (1) are publicly available online in Matlab, Python, and R.
